entry.title: Migrating Integration Flows with JDBC on Cloud Foundry While Using SAP HANA on Neo
entry.content:
Migrating integration flows from SAP's Neo environment to Cloud Foundry (CF) can be a complex process, especially when dealing with extensive JDBC requirements. This blog post outlines a practical example of how to manage such a migration while keeping the backend database in Neo.

#Use-case

In scenarios where the backend database is hosted on Neo, you may prefer to migrate it at the very end of the transition process. The outlined approach allows all migrated integration flows in Cloud Foundry and existing flows in Neo to continue interacting with the Neo database seamlessly.

To begin, ensure your HANA service is properly set up in your Neo account. This setup is crucial for maintaining database connectivity during the migration process.

(Sample) Active HANA service on Neo

# Migration Procedure

1. Exposing HANA Service via SCC
Utilize the Service Channel Concept (SCC) to expose your HANA service. This method ensures that both migrated and existing integration flows can access the Neo database without interruption. See  Configure a Service Channel for an SAP HANA Database.

3. Configuring JDBC Data Source in Cloud Integration

Next, configure the JDBC data source within the Cloud Integration capability environment. This step is essential for establishing a reliable connection to the Neo database. To add a JDBC data source, see Manage JDBC  Data Source

 

#Sample Integration Flow

Here's a sample integration flow designed to read data from an employee table in the Neo database. This example demonstrates how integration flows can be executed successfully, ensuring data consistency and accessibility.

 

  • Execution Results

The execution results confirm that the integration flow can consume the HANA database on Neo via the SCC service channel.

In summary, this approach allows organizations to maintain database connectivity during the migration of integration flows from Neo to Cloud Foundry, ensuring a smooth transition without immediate database migration.

entry.title: IDOCs are Still Safe for SAP S/4HANA - SAP Clean Core Extensibility Level B
entry.content:
Intro 

IDOCs are safe to use in SAP S/4HANA programs—and if anyone tells you otherwise, point them to this blog to learn more. IDOCs are now officially part of SAP Clean Core Extensibility! That’s the big news from updated SAP Guidelines (OSS Note 3578329 – Frameworks, Technologies and Development Patterns in Context of Clean Core Extensibility).

This ends the myth that IDOCs are “dead.” They are not. They’re preserved as SAP Clean Core Level B Extensibility, which means your existing IDOC investments are safe. Let’s explore four perspectives—integration, monitoring and error handling, performance, and testing—to see where APIs are recommended first, and where IDOCs still bring value.

1. Integration Perspective

SAP’s recommendation for new development in S/4HANA is clear: use modern integration technologies such as APIs, events, or OData services. They are the strategic direction and best fit for greenfield or transformation projects. That said, not all projects require reinvention. If your business processes remain largely the same as in ECC, and the goal is to reduce cost and risk, IDOCs can still be used. They are not prohibited, and as long as an IDOC type is not listed as deprecated in the SAP Simplification List, it is safe:
https://help.sap.com/docs/btc/lean-sdt-best-practices/sap-s-4hana-simplification-analysis?locale=en-US Because IDOCs are now Clean Core Level B Extensibility, continuing with them is fully supported in SAP S/4HANA on-premise and SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud. They offer a pragmatic path to de-risk projects and leverage existing know-how. 

2. Monitoring and Error Handling Perspective

For new interfaces, SAP recommends using AIF (Application Interface Framework) to handle monitoring, error management, and business validations. AIF provides a powerful, unified monitoring layer, and in many cases it comes license-free (for standard SAP interfaces delivered in namespaces like /SDSLS or /LEEDI, or in CFIN, Document Compliance, or S/4HANA Public Cloud). Where APIs are deployed, AIF bridges the gap between technical payloads and business-friendly monitoring.

IDOCs still have a strong card here: their monitoring capabilities are mature, well-known, and integrated into standard SAP transactions. Functional users know how to work with WE02, BD87, and standard reprocessing flows. This means less training, less overhead, and faster resolution in day-to-day operations.

In other words: AIF is recommended, but IDOCs deliver proven stability in monitoring and error handling.

3. Performance Perspective

APIs are the recommended way forward, but they come with a structural tradeoff: their payloads are larger and typically handle transactions individually. This makes them more verbose and sometimes less efficient for high-volume use cases. IDOCs, in contrast, have long supported bundling, batching, and parallel processing at scale. They’ve been the backbone of high-volume EDI and SAP-to-SAP integrations for decades, and their ability to handle millions of documents daily is field-proven. So while APIs are the strategic choice for new designs, IDOCs remain a safe performance option for scenarios with heavy data throughput.

4. Testing Perspective

Testing support for APIs exists (for example, with SXI_MONITOR), but it is more technical and often requires additional training for functional teams. For IDOCs, simulation and reprocessing are familiar to almost every SAP functional consultant. Tools like WE19 and BD87 make IDOC testing and troubleshooting accessible, reducing dependency on specialist skills.

For projects that need to standardize and automate testing across both APIs and IDOCs, solutions like Int4 Suite provide simulation and test automation capabilities that unify all SAP integration scenarios. You can learn more on how to test and simulate SAP integrations in this SAP learning Course: Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization So while APIs are recommended for new developments, IDOCs still offer ease of testing and proven tooling, especially in brownfield projects.

Conclusion

The strategic path forward in SAP S/4HANA is built on APIs, events, and frameworks like AIF. That’s the official recommendation, and it should guide greenfield and transformation projects. But IDOCs are far from obsolete. They are officially part of Clean Core extensibility, safe to use in both on-premise and private cloud, and carry unique advantages in performance, monitoring, and ease of testing. That makes them not only supported, but still a pragmatic and safe choice when the situation calls for stability, cost reduction, and risk mitigation.

entry.title: Issue and Send Verifiable Credentials
entry.content:
In the evolving landscape of digital ecosystems, verifiable credentials (VCs) have emerged as a powerful tool for establishing trust and enabling secure data sharing. This article outlines the process by which an issuer can create and issue a verifiable credential with SAPs BTP service Decentralized Identity Verification based on a predefined schema, ensuring consistency and authenticity. Following issuance, the credential is securely transferred to the holder, who can use it to participate in a dataspace. For example, within the Catena-X dataspace - a collaborative network enabling trusted data sharing in the automotive and manufacturing sectors - the holder could present their VC to identify themselves in a data sharing use case, ensuring secure and seamless interaction.

Pre-Conditions for Issuance 

Before issuing a verifiable credential, several pre-conditions related to the participating entities, credential configuration, and schema setup must be fulfilled.

  1. A Holder Tenant with an Identity (DID) and Trust List Configuration. The holder, who will receive and own the verifiable credential, must have a valid Decentralized Identifier (DID). This DID uniquely represents the holder within the system, enabling them to securely interact with the issuer and verifiers. Additionally, the issuer’s DID must be added to the holder’s trust list. The trust list is critical as it ensures that the holder only accepts verifiable credentials from selected issuers. For example, in Catena-X, this ensures that only accredited organizations acting as trusted credential issuers can issue verifiable credentials to participants.
  2. An Issuer Tenant with an Identity (DID). The issuer, as mentioned earlier, must have a valid DID representing their secure digital identity. This DID is essential for signing and legitimizing the verifiable credentials, allowing other participants in the ecosystem to independently validate their authenticity and trustworthiness. 
  3. A Schema for the Verifiable Credential. The verifiable credential should adhere to a defined schema that specifies its structure and attributes. The schema serves as a standardized blueprint, ensuring that the data within the credential such as names, dates, or unique identifiers is understood and interoperable across all parties in the ecosystem. 
  4. Configure the Issuer: Once the schema is created, the issuer must configure the credential type that they will issue based on that schema. For each credential type the issuer can specify whether the credential requests are processed automatically or manually and if it is tied to its predefined schema. 

Issue Verifiable Credentials

  1. Navigate to credential section and click on the Issue button to start the issuance process.
  2. Configure meta data of the verifiable credential (validity settings and choose signing dentity)


    • Set Expiration: Enter the expiration date and time for the VC (how long the credential will be valid)
    • Revocation List (Optional): If the credential should be revocable, enable the option to assign it to a revocation list and select the appropriate revocation list if more than one exists.
    • Signing Identity: Select the DID (Decentralized Identifier) under your control that will be used to sign the credential. 

  3. Add additional contexts (advanced): Additional contexts allow interoperability with extended schemas or domain-specific vocabularies.

  4. Define credential details


    • Select a credential type supported by your issuer, published via the issuer metadata endpoint. These types can be configured in the issuer settings. Holders may only accept specific credential types from your issuer, so choose accordingly.
    • Select Schema: Choose the schema that defines the structure and required attributes of the credential. The holder’s wallet will use this schema to validate and display the credential.
    • Fill in Mandatory Attributes: Based on the schema, a dynamic form will be displayed. Enter all required attributes (e.g., name, date of birth, license number). Ensure all fields marked as mandatory are filled; incomplete credentials may be rejected by the holder. Add any additional, non-mandatory attributes as needed.

  5. Finalize verifiable credential:


    • Immediate signing of the verifiable credential or in a later point in time
    • Immediate or deferred offer: Decide if the credential should be offered to the holder immediately after signing or stored for future delivery.

The verifiable credential is now created and can be sent directly to the holder, or, if preferred, stored and delivered upon the holder’s request at a later time. All issued credentials are visible to the issuer within the wallet, allowing the issuer to select an issued credential in the future for purposes such as revocation or re-offering to the holder.

API

The same process described in the user interface can also be performed programmatically using the API, which provides an endpoint for the combined creation, signing, and offering of credentials in a single call, or, alternatively, allows you to perform these steps individually with separate API calls.

POST {srv}/api/v2.0.0/credentials
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
    "application": "Dataspace",
    "payload": {
      "offer" : {
        "content": {
            "@context": [
                "https://www.w3.org/2018/credentials/v1",
                "https://www.w3.org/2018/credentials/examples/v1"
            ],
            "name": "BPN",
            "description": "BPN",
            "expirationDate": "2025-11-25T16:51:22.000Z",
            "type": [
                "BpnCredential"
            ],
            "issuer": "{issuerDID}",
            "credentialSubject": {
                "id": "{holderDID}",
                "bpn": "BPNL000000002"
            },
            "credentialStatus": {
                "id": "{revocation list}",
                "type": "StatusList2021"
            }            
        }, 
        "signature": {
          "proofMechanism": "external",
          "proofType": "jwt"
        }
      }
    }
}

Next step:

entry.title: Introduction to SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) and Related SSI Blog Posts
entry.content:
SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) is SAP’s solution for enabling Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI). With DIV, organizations can establish trusted digital identities, issue and manage verifiable credentials, and empower organizations with secure digital interactions. To help you get started with DIV and explore its full potential, we have published a comprehensive series of blog posts covering setup, configuration, usage, and practical SSI use cases.

Below you will find a categorized list of these blogs for easy navigation:

  1. Setting Up Your SSI Environment
    1. Provisioning SAP’s Self-Sovereign Identity Wallet: This blog post will guide you through the process of creating a tenant of the DIV using SAP’s provisioning admin dashboard or API.

  2. Using DIV
    1. Preparing an SSI Wallet for a Holder: In today’s interconnected digital landscape, secure and decentralized identity management is crucial for seamless and trusted data exchange. To facilitate this, SAP provides DIV, a Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) wallet solution that enables organizations to participate in SSI use cases.
    2. Creating an SSI Wallet for an Issuer: SAP’s Decentralized Identity Verification service enables organizations to manage and verify digital identities securely. While the Holder Wallet is primarily used to receive and present verifiable credentials, it can be extended to issue verifiable credentials as well.
    3. Configure the Trust List: A trust configuration is a declarative policy, defining trusted entities (issuers). This configuration typically includes the trusted issuers' decentralized identifiers (DIDs) and optionally a list of credential types.
    4. Issue and Send Verifiable Credentials: This article outlines the process by which an issuer can create and issue a verifiable credential with SAPs BTP service Decentralized Identity Verification based on a predefined schema, ensuring consistency and authenticity.
    5. Transferring Verifiable Credentials with the Eclipse Dataspace Decentralized Claims Protocol (DCP): This blog post explores two core ways VCs are transferred from an issuer wallet tenant to a holder wallet tenant using Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) focusing on automation options available to both issuers and holders.
  3. Use Case Descriptions
    1. Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI): A Usage Catalyst for Data Spaces: A data space is a secure, decentralized framework that enables organizations to share and collaborate on data while keeping control. The exchange of data between companies within a dataspace ecosystem is essential an is securely enabled with the help of DIV.
    2. Using Self-Sovereign Identity and Questionnaire Vouchers for Demand Collection: In the fast-evolving semiconductor industry, understanding market demand is both critical and challenging. Modern data spaces offer new opportunities for more targeted and privacy-preserving demand collection. One innovative approach combines Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) and verifiable credential (VC) vouchers to streamline questionnaire management within these data spaces.

Explore these resources to learn how SAP DIV can power your journey toward trustworthy, decentralized digital identity and unlock new business value with SSI.

entry.title: How Modernization with SAP Integration Suite Looks After Go-live
entry.content:
How Modernization with SAP Integration Suite Looks After Go-live

When businesses talk about modernization, the conversation often ends at “faster integrations, lower costs, and improved agility.” But the real story begins after go-live. That’s when companies discover how much integration truly influences their day-to-day confidence, decision-making, and ability to grow.

SAP Integration Suite isn’t just a connector between systems. It’s a foundation that determines how reliably data flows, how resilient operations become, and how quickly businesses can act. Over the years, I’ve seen clients across various industries realize unexpected benefits, some of which only become apparent once the project is complete.

Beyond Speed and Cost: The Lasting Impact

Yes, speed, agility, and efficiency matter. However, the most significant changes often occur on the business side: enhanced resilience during disruptions, smoother compliance, faster demand response, and stronger partner ecosystems. These outcomes go far beyond what you see in the initial project plan.

Let’s look at how these benefits show up in practice.

Case Story 1: Real-Time Sales for FMCG

I once worked with a global FMCG company where the team told me: “By the time we see yesterday’s sales numbers, the shelves are already empty today.”

The problem wasn’t lack of data, they had plenty, but it was buried under custom code and overnight batch jobs. Promotions went live, yet replenishment only followed the next morning. This cost both sales and credibility.

With SAP Integration Suite, the story changed. Event Mesh enabled real-time updates across SAP and non-SAP applications. APIs replaced brittle custom objects. Sales data became same-day data. Planners acted instantly, stockouts dropped, and system performance improved by nearly 50%. Retailers noticed the difference too.

Case Story 2: Compliance and Cost Reduction in Pharma

Pharmaceutical companies face a unique challenge: balancing strict compliance with the pressure to modernize their operations. I remember working closely with a global pharma client that was still running on SAP PO and several legacy middleware tools. Every conversation revealed frustration; IT teams were stretched thin, compliance reports were painstakingly assembled from multiple sources, and maintenance costs continued to climb.

When we introduced SAP Integration Suite, the change was tangible almost immediately. We rebuilt interfaces into modular iFlows with centralized error handling, while APIs became the go-to standard for both internal and partner communications. During one workshop, the compliance team’s eyes lit up as real-time dashboards provided them with the visibility they had been seeking for years. By the end of the project, the company had cut maintenance costs by 40%, strengthened regulatory compliance, and enabled real-time data exchange across functions — all on a modern, event-driven integration backbone built to scale with their business.

Case Story 3: Strengthening the Ecosystem in Manufacturing

I recall visiting the IT operations center of a global power transmission manufacturer, operating in 30+ countries. They were still relying on SAP Neo, which had served them well initially but had become rigid and unable to support multi-cloud strategies. The team was candid: every new initiative felt like a gamble, and IT was constantly firefighting integration issues.

Migrating to SAP Integration Suite on Cloud Foundry changed the dynamics. Key manufacturing and logistics applications were re-platformed, and APIs and integrations were rebuilt for multi-cloud compatibility. Real-time monitoring gave IT a level of visibility and control they had never experienced. I remember the moment the IT director said, “We finally feel like we can see everything, and trust it.”

With that being said, the result was remarkable: 50% faster data exchange, full transparency, and a seamless partner experience. Integration was no longer just “plumbing”; it became a strategic lever that strengthened ecosystem collaboration and supported global business growth.

 

The Hidden Wins of Modernization

Some benefits don’t make it into the launch-day slide deck but show their value every day:

  • Resilience: Processes continue even when one system falters, thanks to monitoring, retries, and built-in error handling.

  • Confidence: CIOs and IT leaders gain visibility into integrations, reducing the stress of hidden risks.

  • Governance: Centralized logs and traces simplify audits, cutting weeks of prep time.

  • Agility: Businesses adapt quickly to market changes because data flows freely across systems and regions.

These shifts are as valuable as the traditional metrics like cost savings or speed. They change how businesses operate — and how confidently teams make decisions.

In Short

Modernization with SAP Integration Suite is not just about connecting systems. It’s about giving businesses the resilience to run without constant firefighting, the confidence to innovate without fear, and the agility to grow without hesitation.

Every company faces unique challenges, but the pattern remains the same: once integrations are modernized, businesses move faster, partners collaborate more easily, and IT can finally focus on value instead of survival. That’s the true impact of SAP Integration Suite, the benefits that appear after go-live, and the foundation it builds for the future.

entry.title: Transferring Verifiable Credentials with the Eclipse Dataspace Decentralized Claims Protocol (DCP)
entry.content:
In the era of Self-sovereign Identity (SIS), verifiable credentials (VCs) are becoming a cornerstone. Organizations and individuals can now issue, request, and present attestations  without relying on a central authority, enabled by emerging standards and protocols such as the Decentral Claims Protocol (DCP). This blog post explores two core ways VCs are transferred from an issuer wallet tenant to a holder wallet tenant using Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) focusing on automation options available to both issuers and holders.

 

Two VC Transfer Patterns

With DCP, there are two main patterns for moving a verifiable credential from the issuer's environment to the holder's:

Holder-Initiated Credential Request

Holder requests VCs:

  • The holder launches their VC request app and picks the issuer from which they wish to request credentials.
  • The app pulls published credential types (from the issuer's metadata endpoint), ensuring the holder can only request credentials the issuer offers. 

     
  • The users selects the credential types to be requested
  • Next, the holder selects which identity to use (think multiple DIDs or personas in their wallet).
  • A request for the selected credential type(s), tied to the chosen identity, is dispatched to the issuer.

 

API to Request VCs

This feature can also be consumed via API, enabling deep integration into other applications and seamless automation of decentralized credential workflows.

POST {srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/requestCredentials/{app_name}
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}
{
  "requestedCredentials": [
    {
      "credentialType": "BpnCredential",
      "format": "vcdm11_jwt"
    }
  ],
  "issuerDid": "{issuerDID}",
  "holderDid": "{holderDID}"
}

 

Issuer processes credential requests:

The issuer receives the request in their inbox. They review, approve, and send back the requested VC(s) to the holder. Alternatively, they may have to first create the credential before sending it.

Automation Option: Issuers can preconfigure their wallet to auto-respond to requests - if the VC is already ready. However, if credentials are not yet generated, or if the holder requests a set of credentials where not all are available, manual intervention is required.

Holder receives VCs:

Once complete, the holder receives the VC, visible in the credential overview section of their admin app. 


 

API to Respond to VC Requests

This feature can also be consumed via API, enabling deep integration into other applications and seamless automation of decentralized credential workflows.

Issuer Get Received Credential Requests

GET {srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/credentialRequestsReceived
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

 

Response to VC Request -> Send Response to Request

POST {srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/credentialRequestsReceived/{requestId}/send
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

 

Issuer-Initiated Credential Offer

Sometimes, the issuer wants to proactively notify holders that a credential is available or due for a refresh (e.g., before expiration or after key rotation). This issuing pattern is essential for refreshing credentials (e.g., after expiration or key revocation) because the issuer can push a new offer seamlessly, keeping the holder's status up to date with minimal friction.

Issuer sends offer

The issuer navigates their app to the relevant issued VC, opens the action menu, and sends a credential offer to the selected holder. The offer notifies the holder that a credential is prepped for them and can be retrieved.

Holder receives offer

The holder's wallet receives the offer. Here, behavior depends on their wallet's configuration:

  • Manual: The holder reviews the offer and chooses to make a credential request to receive it.
  • Automated: If the holder has marked the issuer as trusted with auto-accept enabled, the wallet will automatically convert the offer into a credential request and handle the entire transfer without manual clicks.

API to Offer VCs

This feature can also be consumed via API, enabling deep integration into other applications and seamless automation of decentralized credential workflows.

 

POST {div_wallet_srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/credentialOffers/send
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}
{
  "credentials": [
    "{vcId}"
  ]
}

 

Flexible Automation for Different Needs

A core strength of DIV is its support for both manual and automated flows. Depending on policy, user preference, and business process, any step on either issuer or holder side can be handled by a human or managed entirely by the wallet’s auto-configuration. In highly regulated or sensitive use-cases, both sides might want maximum manual review steps before issuing or accepting credentials. In high-scale, low-touch environments, the entire process can be embedded and fully automated.

 

Summary

Decentralized identity verification, enables seamless, secure transfer of verifiable credentials across wallet tenants. Whether initiated by holders seeking new credentials or by proactive issuers keeping credentials fresh, DCP allows maximum flexibility for both manual and automated workflows letting each participant tailor the process to their risk profile and user experience needs.

  • Decentralized Claims Protocol

entry.title: SAP BTP: Creating Connections at Supply Chain Connect
entry.content:
There’s excitement building in the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) team, as we get ready for the SAP Connect event, which will run from 6-8 October in Las Vegas. Of course, SAP Connect is different this year, with five events offered in one location, where attendees can enjoy a conference experience focused on their own Line of Business. Three of my colleagues have already been busy publishing blogs about SAP BTP topics you’ll be able to find at the conference, ijoaquin on Spend Management, rnoia on HCM and joanneks focusing on technology topics. Not wishing to feel left out, I thought that I would share a blog that focuses on my area of interest, SAP BTP for Supply Chain.

In working with my SAP Supply Chain Management colleagues on topics for the Supply Chain Connect event, we’ve decided to focus on SAP BTP capabilities that go to the heart of a “connected” supply chain, where integration and automation are key to creating agility and resilience. entry.title: New CI Pipeline Restart Extension features: supporting new Pipeline package and improved Restart Job
entry.content:
We are excited to announce the release of Cloud Integration Pipeline Extension - Restart via Data Store in version 1.0.1.

This update introduces several powerful new features and improvements:

  • Supports new integration packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration and allows flexible linkage of Generic Pipeline copies to the Pipeline Stages.
  • Enhanced Restart Job Integration Flow:
    • Generic Job Profile to restart all integration scenarios defined in the Partner Directory through the Pipeline Framework.
    • New configuration options to persist the Job Log.
    • New Integration Flow "Pipeline API - Restart Job Log" to retrieve both the Restart Job run list and detailed log data (if log persistence is enabled).
  • Improved configuration and monitoring: New parameters (such as "NotOlderThanHours" for Restart Job), several bug fixes, enriched monitoring headers, and better exception handling.

With these enhancements, version 1.0.1 delivers more flexibility, transparency, and control when managing restarts in your Cloud Integration pipelines.

Integration Package content

New package consists of six Integration Flows, one central Script Collection and one Value Mapping. 2 new artifacts have been added:

  • Pipeline API – Restart Job Log (Optional). This Integration Flow enables API-based retrieval of stored Job Logs. It is built on top of the standard Message Processing Logs (MPL) API and allows either to retrieve the restart job log or to query MPL details of executed Restart Jobs.
  • Value Mapping to determine Pipeline Stage (Optional). The Data Store Entry Name includes a 2-letter code for the Pipeline Stage, derived from the technical name of Pipeline IFlow where the error occurred. This Value Mapping allows to link custom IFlow copies to their Pipeline Stage.

Support for new Pipeline integration packages

The new Cloud Integration Pipeline packages introduce Integration Flows with updated technical IDs that include the version marker “v2”. To ensure compatibility, these new IFlow IDs have been added to the stage determination logic.

In addition, the latest Pipeline version now propagates the MPL ID of the source Pipeline IFlow to the custom error handling IFlow. This allows the Data Store entry name to be built using the original source MPL ID, rather than the MPL ID of the custom error handling flow (as was the case in version 1 of the Cloud Integration Pipeline package).

Pipeline Stage Determination

Each Data Store entry name includes the mandatory attribute Pipeline Stage, which indicates where the exception occurred. In the new version of the Restart Extension, the pipeline stage is resolved through a two-step process. If neither step succeeds, a default value is assigned: Stage (NA) or "Not Assigned".

  1. Technical ID Prefix Check. The system first evaluates the prefix of the source pipeline Integration Flow’s technical ID. This was the only approach available in version 1.0.0. For example, if you copy a generic Integration Flow to create a receiver-specific outbound pipeline IFlow, the technical ID must start with the correct stage prefix:
    com.sap.integration.cloud.pipeline.v2.generic.step06.outbound.myCustomIFlow is resolved to stage (OB).
  2. Value Mapping Check. If the stage cannot be determined from the prefix, the new version applies a Value Mapping. This mapping links custom IFlow technical IDs to specific pipeline stages, allowing you to flexibly assign non-standard technical IDs to the correct stage (see screenshot).

Generic (Default) Job Profile

In version 1.0.0, the Restart Job IFlow could restart only specific interfaces defined in the Job Profile. One of the most common feedback points was the need for a generic Restart Job, similar to what is available in SAP PO, that could restart all integration scenarios configured for the Cloud Integration Pipeline.

This capability has now been added. With the Generic Restart Job Profile, all scenarios where the Partner ID is determined using the Alternative Partner approach can be restarted in one go. The configuration effort is minimal: the only requirement is that the Job Profile status is set to "active."

Optionally, you can exclude specific integration scenarios from the Generic Restart Job by providing them in the parameter InterfacePidExclusionList.

New Job Profile Parameters

The Restart Job Profile now supports additional optional parameters that extend flexibility and monitoring:

  • NotOlderThanHours. In version 1.0.0, filtering was only possible with the static interval parameters TimeFrom and TimeTo. In the new version, if TimeFrom is not explicitly set, this parameter can dynamically calculate it as: 
TimeFrom = (Job run start timestamp) – (Configured number of hours in NotOlderThanHours)
  • RestartJobLog. By default, the job log is stored only in memory within the message header jobLogHeader (accessible only when Trace is activated). With this parameter, you can define where and how the job log is stored:
    • attach – the job log is attached to the MPL of the Restart Job IFlow, using the Restart Job ID as MPL Attachment name.
    • persist – the job log is persisted in the database using the Persist Message step.
    • custom – the job log is sent via a ProcessDirect extension to a custom-built IFlow. In this case, an additional parameter must be maintained in the Job Profile restartJobLogExitEndpoint with the value of ProcessDirect endpoint.

Pipeline API Operations

A new API Integration Flow Pipeline API – Restart Job Log has been introduced in the latest package version. This Integration Flow enables API-based retrieval of Restart Job Logs, provided that the RestartJobLog parameter of the Job Profile is set to either "attach" or "persist".

The following queries are supported:

  • Retrieve the restart job log for a specific Restart Job instance by supplying either the MPL ID of the Restart Job IFlow or the unique Restart Job ID.
  • Query MPL details of executed Restart Jobs based on selection criteria, in order to obtain the MPL ID of the Restart Job IFlow or the unique Restart Job ID.

For further details, see the updated Configuration Guide included in the package.

entry.title: Int4 Suite Agents Empowers Functional Consultants To Test Integrated SAP S/4HANA Business Processes
entry.content:
Introduction 

Integrated business processes are the bloodstream of SAP systems. Every Sales Order, Purchase Order, Delivery, and Invoice has to flow smoothly, not just within SAP, but across EDI partners (customer, vendors, 3PL partners) banks, warehouses, tax portals.

Here’s the paradox: SAP S/4HANA projects have plenty of sophisticated automation tools, but they rarely help functional consultants in their manual tests. Instead, those tools get pushed into the narrow niche of automation testers. Functional consultants treat them like mythical dragons, complicated, dangerous, and likely to drag them away from their real work into procedural swamps.

The result? Slow testing cycles, dependency on integration specialists, and endless waiting for external partners to provide messages or confirmations.

Changing the story with simulation agents

The better path is not to force functional consultants into scripting or automation frameworks, but to give them simulation agents that mimic the system environment.

Instead of saying: “learn a test framework and run automated scripts,” we can say: “here are agents that simulate your missing EDI partner, your unavailable 3rd party/legacy system and you can test with them right now.”

This changes the game:

  • No competition with automation teams.
  • No learning curve with complex frameworks and procedural delays.
  • Consultants get something they instantly understand: realistic test conditions on demand, using actual historical production data.

How Int4 Suite Agents Work

With Int4 Suite, simulation agents provide a simple interface: the consultant performs the transaction in SAP, the agent feeds in authentic historical test data, and then automatically checks whether the newly generated EDI or non-EDI message matches what was sent in production.

Below are examples of key agents and how they fit into typical integrated OTC and P2P processes

Figure - meet the Int4 Suite Agents 

EDI Partner Agent (based on historical data)

Role: Replays authentic production EDI messages from trading partners (ORDERS, DESADV, INVOIC).

How it works:

  • Consultant performs the transaction in SAP (e.g., creates delivery, sends invoice).
  • Agent provides historical test data from previously exchanged documents.
  • Agent automatically compares the newly generated EDI message with the production one for a similar case.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant in the OTC team replays historical ORDERS from the largest customer and verifies whether, after pricing condition changes, the system still calculates correctly.
  • Consultant tests goods receipt with historical DESADV data; agent compares the new EDI message against the production one.
  • Consultant issues a sales invoice (INVOIC) and agent validates it against the original production invoice, checking VAT rules.

Figure - Select Historical EDI messages from Production system which need to be rerun on Test System 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant creates a purchase order; agent provides a historical ORDRSP where the supplier delivered partially, then compares the new outbound message.
  • Agent simulates a supplier INVOIC and verifies whether workflows behave the same after configuration changes.

Figure - manipulate the historical/production landscape EDI message data before sending that to the test environment

Unavailable System Agent (Non-SAP)

Role: Simulates external systems (banks, customs, WMS/TMS, tax portals) with historical production communications.

How it works:

  • Consultant runs the business process in SAP.
  • Agent injects historical test data from the external system.
  • Agent compares the new outbound message with the original production one.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant tests e-invoicing using a historically rejected invoice; agent checks whether the new output matches the original and if the new rules handle it.
  • Consultant tests shipment confirmations with historical WMS responses.

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bank payments; agent supplies historical payment files and checks the new output structure.
  • Consultant tests tax submissions; agent provides historical records and compares new vs. old messages.

Figure - Display the historical EDI data used on production landscape before rerunning that on the test environment 

Historical Data Agent

Role: The production message librarian, replays large volumes or special cases directly from production.

How it works:

  • Consultant triggers transactions in SAP (bulk orders, invoices, returns).
  • Agent provides the historical payloads.
  • Agent verifies test messages against the production equivalents.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant replays a “Black Friday” scenario with 10,000 ORDERS; agent validates each new EDI message against its production twin.
  • Consultant tests credit memo flows from historical complaint cases.

Figure – run many historical messages on the test environment for bulk testing purposes 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bulk supplier invoices; agent validates the outputs against production.
  • Consultant tests blocked spare-parts orders with historical references.

Integration Consultant Agent

Role: A technical assistant that retrieves and compares messages from middleware layers (PI/PO, CPI).

How it works:

  • Consultant executes the business process in SAP.
  • Agent fetches the historical integration payload.
  • Agent highlights differences between new and historical messages.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant creates a sales order; agent compares the IDoc/XML message with the historical SAP Integration Suite payload.
  • Agent highlights mapping differences at field level after configuration changes.

Figure – fetch an EDI payload produced by the integration platform (SAP Integration Suite, etc.) from a newly created business document and compare with the historical one from the production landscape without asking SAP Integration Consultant for help 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant enters a supplier invoice; agent pulls historical Ariba-CPI payload and checks consistency.
  • Agent validates purchase order messages across production and test runs.

Why it matters for SAP S/4HANA projects

In S/4HANA transformations, the external world doesn’t care about your internal redesigns. Customers, suppliers, and banks still expect exactly the same messages they used to get. Outbound and inbound interfaces are fragile bridges that must remain stable.

By equipping functional consultants with Int4 Suite agents:

  • Test cycles shorten dramatically.
  • Reliance on external partners and scarce integration resources drops.
  • Confidence in end-to-end quality rises.

This isn’t about replacing automation experts or integration teams. It’s about enabling functional consultants to independently confirm that what leaves SAP (or comes into it) is still what the outside world expects.

It’s the missing puzzle piece for smooth, low-friction testing of integrated business processes in SAP transformations.

Agentic AI Testing for Greenfield S/4HANA Outbound Interfaces - Part 1
Int4 Suite — your SAP Joule testbed and skills builder
Process-Aware Agentic Testing of SAP with Int4 Suite

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite - Content Modifier
entry.content:
Content Modifier

Content Modifier is a tool used in integration processes to adjust incoming messages by modifying headers, properties, or the message body to meet specific requirements.

Content Modifier has 4 types:

  1. General.
  2. Message Header.
  3. Exchange Property.
  4. Message Body.

General:

In General We can change the Content Modifier Name as you want.

 

Message Header:

These carry metadata about the message, such as content type or routing information.

Note: Metadata refers to information about the message itself, not the content of the message.

 

Exchange Property:

Exchange Property is a key/value pair used to store data temporarily during message processing. It's a powerful and flexible way to pass information between steps in an integration flow. 

 

Message Body:

In message body there are:

  1. Type – In type there are two types Constant - for fixed body & Expression - for Custom/Expression Language body.
  2. Body – We can call the headers & Properties which were created in the before fields and we can enter the custom body.

 

In Content Modifier, we can define values with source types according to requirement:

Constant:

  • To set a fixed value, Best for static data that doesn't change.
  • Example: Country = India

Expression:

  • Dynamic values, Allows you to use simple Expression Language.
  • Syntax: ${header.<name>}, ${property.<name>}

Global Variable:

  • Refers to values defined as Global Variables in the CPI runtime.
  • Used in more complex scenarios and reusable scripts.
  • When you define global settings used across many flows.

Header:

  • Gets the value from an existing message header.
  • Example: You may copy a header like Authorization into a new one.
  • When values are already present in headers and you want to reuse or forward them.

Local Variable:

  • Used for values created temporarily during the flow (like in scripts).
  • Best for temporary or calculated values.

Number Range:

  • Auto-generates a number from a configured number range.
  • Can be used to generate sequential IDs.

Property:

  • Gets the value from a message property (set in Content Modifier or other steps).
  • Example: Set city as a property earlier, then reuse it here.
  • Properties are used for temporary storage during flow execution.

XPath: Extracts data from the XML message body using an XPath expression.

  • Example: /root/customer/city

 

 

Content Modifier Example:

  • In Message Header - City Name added with value of Guntur with Constant type.

  • In Exchange Property – timestamp as Name with Expression Source type & Source Value is ${date:now:yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss}

  • In Message body we called the names added in Header & Property.

Time & Address are printed in the output body as shown in above image.

entry.title: Extensibility in the Age of AI: Why ABCD Is Easier (and Smarter) Than You Think
entry.content:
The CTO’s Concern

Not long ago, during a client conversation, a CTO expressed a concern that resonated deeply:

“We need to extend our system. But every time someone says ‘let’s customize this,’ I feel we’re piling risk. And now with AI coming, I’m afraid our mess gets worse.”

That statement captures the heart of a challenge many SAP customers face. Customization has been both the strength and the Achilles’ heel of enterprise landscapes. It allows us to adapt, innovate, and differentiate — but it often comes with technical debt, upgrade pain, and hidden complexity.

Why Extensibility Matters More in the AI Era

Let’s pause here. Ten years ago, if you added a Z-table or tweaked a user exit, the worst-case scenario was some testing pain during an upgrade. Today?

  • If your data model is inconsistent, your AI forecasts won’t align with reality.
  • If your logic is buried in old exits, Joule copilots can’t “see” your processes.
  • If your core is brittle, cloud updates feel like risks, not opportunities.

In other words: extensibility is no longer just about “making it work.” It’s about making AI possible.

And now, with SAP’s AI ambitions accelerating — embedded copilots, Joule agents, and business data clouds powering predictive intelligence — the messy customizations of the past risk becoming blockers for the future.

This is where ABCD extensibility comes in. Far from being abstract jargon, it’s a practical compass to guide enterprises on how to extend the system smartly, safely, and in a way that enables AI instead of hindering it.

The ABCD Levels: A Human Explanation

SAP’s ABCD framework doesn’t exist to confuse us — it exists to help customers navigate the grey space between innovation and stability.

Here’s the official breakdown, with real-world translation:

A Short Story: The MV45AFZZ Debate

Anyone who has worked in SAP Sales and Distribution knows the legendary include MV45AFZZ. For decades, it’s been the go-to spot for developers to implement custom sales order checks, validations, and logic.

At one client, a senior developer proudly said, “We’ve been using MV45AFZZ for 15 years, and it works just fine. Why change?”

And he wasn’t wrong. In many ways, that’s a Level B extensibility choice: small, controlled, and serving the business well. (In fact, SAP even documented this in SAP Note 3578329, proving that not all ‘old-school’ practices are bad.)

The problem comes when dozens of such exits pile up, undocumented, with overlapping logic — and suddenly the system feels like a house of cards.

Here’s the twist: ABCD extensibility is not about banning MV45AFZZ or exits. It’s about putting them in the right place, with the right intent.

The IDoc Question: Clean or Not?

One of the most common debates I hear is: “We use IDocs everywhere. Are they clean core?”

The answer: Yes, IDocs are safe — they fall under Level B.

SAP clarified this in the IDoc Clean Core blog.

Why? Because IDocs are:

  • Officially documented.
  • Supported by SAP.
  • Used for integration and still relevant in S/4HANA.

That said, if you’re starting a greenfield cloud project, you may want to move toward APIs and Event Mesh (Level A) instead. But if you’ve got an existing landscape with IDocs, don’t panic — they’re not “unclean.”

Real-World Scenarios: Which Level to Choose?

Why This Matters for AI

AI copilots like Joule don’t “guess.” They rely on:

  • Stable APIs (Level A).
  • Clear data models (A & B).
  • Trusted logic (not buried in Level C/D).

If your system is full of Level D hacks, AI copilots won’t understand your processes. But if you steer toward A and B (with C monitored), you create an AI-ready enterprise.

 Closing Thought

Extensibility is not the villain. Misuse is.

The ABCD framework gives us a shared language:

  • A when we want innovation + AI without worry.
  • B when proven frameworks like IDocs or MV45AFZZ still serve us.
  • C only if there’s no choice — and we track it closely.
  • D only if we want to leave a headache for the next generation.

So next time someone says “let’s customize,” you don’t need to panic. You just need to ask:

Is this A, B, C, or D? And that one question can mean the difference between a system that blocks AI — and one that accelerates it.

entry.title: What's New in SAP BTP - Q3 2025
entry.content:
This third quarter brought some helpful innovation highlights for SAP Business Technology Platform, that we’re excited to share with you! The Q3 Innobytes demonstrate the progress we made in SAP BTP over the last months. Check out the video below and explore the latest features in Application Development, Joule and more. Enjoy watching!

 

App Dev Highlights

AI-powered Capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone

In the first demo, three new AI capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone are demonstrated to help you work smarter and more efficiently.

With AI Summarization, you can create a concise summary of long documents within seconds. Simply find the content in your workspace and click Summarize to save time and work smarter.

To make engaging with content easier, you can access AI Comment Generation via the AI icon to generate contextual comments, helping respond quickly and intelligently. 

To support content creation, the AI Text Generation helps with drafting an introduction or brainstorming ideas. In the workspace editor, you can ask AI to generate Text and let it support your experience in the SAP Build Work Zone.  

Watch the demo starting at 00:09 to see these innovations in action.

Skill Builder in Joule General Availability

Welcome to Joule Studio, a powerful tool that enables you to create intelligent AI agents and custom-built Joule Skills based on your specific business needs.

The creation of Joule Studio’s AI agent is seamlessly integrated with SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), leveraging its robust security, scalability, and connectivity to SAP systems for maximum efficiency. In this demo, a new Joule Skill is created that automates the workflow of the badge printing process. It automatically generates and prints employee badges by integrating Joule Studio with the SAP HR database, and everything you need for this process is in one place.

Start the demo at 01:51 to get more insights.

Learn more

  • Get Started with Joule Studio
  • Detailed Tutorial
  • SAP Community Blog Page

 

Downtime-Optimized Upgrades for SAP BTP ABAP Environment

SAP BTP ABAP Environment now uses blue-green-fashioned lifecycle management to minimize the downtime during hotfixes and version upgrades.

A recent update demonstrates that switching to a new runtime takes only seconds, with release upgrades targeting about 30 minutes. This innovation aims to make the process more transparent, aligning with downtime more efficiently. With this improvement, we are minimizing downtime and optimizing upgrades! 

This demo uses an example to highlight this innovation further (starting at 03:15).

Learn more

  • SAP BTP ABAP Environment – Maintenance Windows and Major Upgrade Windows in 2025

 

Integration

AI Adapter in SAP Integration Suite

In August, we released an AI adapter for Cloud Integration capability of the SAP Integration Suite on the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).

Available as part of the Standard plan and above, it allows integration flows to interact with Large Language Models, adding AI directly into the integration at runtime. In this demo iflow, a product review is analyzed with OpenAI to enrich them with customer sentiment. This example shows the detection of a negative sentiment in a product review through GPT-5. The adapter is available now for you to try.

Watch this part (starting at 04:29) to get more insights.

Learn more

  • AI Adapter Blog Post
  • AI Adapter on SAP Business Accelerator Hub

 

Data & Analytics

SQL Generation for SAP HANA in Joule

In SAP Build Code, Joule can now automatically generate SAP HANA SQL based on natural language prompts.

You can either execute it directly within the Joule panel or you can copy the SQL command into the SQL Console to perform additional operations or refinements. This integration streamlines workflows, boosts productivity, and reduces errors, eliminating manual coding and tool switching.

This is how it’s done:

  1. Enable SQL generation using object definitions in your workspace’s settings
  2. Navigate to your Joule extension and select the command type HANA SQL
  3. Type your Natural Language Prompt – Joule will then generate and execute the SQL for you
  4. Execute or add operations or refinements to the results

See these steps in action (starting at 05:57).

Learn more

  • Generate SQL from Natural Language using Joule

 

Cross

Modifiable Transport Requests

SAP Cloud Transport Management Service now supports Modifiable Transport Requests, allowing you to test and adjust transport requests in safe test nodes before releasing them to production.

This is how it works:

  1. Create a Modifiable Transport Request with the Create button.
  2. When opening the request, see the Tracking tab that shows the transport landscape and is now open for changes.
  3. Add content to the request and click the Test button to import directly or later and freely add or remove content.
  4. Release the request when testing is completed.

This flexible approach enables adding, removing, or redeploying content as needed, ensuring higher quality and safer deployments. Automation and Integration with other SAP BTP services are planned, so stay tuned for more to come.

To see this demo in action, watch the video (starting at 07:36).

Learn more

  • Modifiable Transport Request Blog Post

Change Point Detection for Custom BTP Apps in SAP Cloud ALM

Running custom apps on SAP BTP embraces Cloud Flexibility with the Clean Core Principle. With the SAP Cloud ALM for Operations, you can monitor SAP and non-SAP applications end-to-end. This feature ensures business continuity and operational efficiency.

Real User Monitoring gives you clear insights into usage by tracking executions, performance, and response times all in one interface. 

If the performance suddenly shifts, Change Point Detection identifies unusual patterns in the performance compared to historical trends. You can then directly navigate to the respective request and even receive alerts or emails when a change point is detected. This helps quick investigation of the issue and ensures smooth operations.

This new feature is highlighted (starting at 08:52).

entry.title: Global Alert Mechanism to Monitor iFlows in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
📌 Introduction

Monitoring integration flows (iFlows) in SAP Integration Suite is critical for ensuring business continuity and proactive issue resolution. While SAP provides standard monitoring tools, many organizations benefit from a global alert mechanism that sends real-time notifications when an iFlow fails or encounters an error.

In this blog, we’ll walk through how to implement a global alert system using Groovy scripting, message properties, and the Mail Adapter to notify stakeholders with detailed error information and direct links to message monitoring.


Below is the image of the Integration Flow I created:

🎯Objective

To create a reusable alert mechanism that:

  • Captures error details from any iFlow.
  • Generates a direct link to the failed message in SAP Integration Suite.
  • Sends an HTML-formatted email with a clickable hyperlink to the monitoring dashboard.

🛠️ Prerequisites

  • Access to SAP Integration Suite (Cloud Integration).
  • Basic knowledge of iFlow design and Groovy scripting.
  • Mail Adapter configured with SMTP settings.

Step 1: Set Up the Tenant Monitoring URL

Add a Content Modifier at the start of your iFlow to set the tenant’s monitoring URL as a property:

Property Name: TenantMoniURL
Value:

https://<your-tenant>.integrationsuite.cfapps.<region>.hana.ondemand.com

Step 2: Generate the Monitoring URL with Groovy

Add a Groovy Script step after the Content Modifier:

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;

def Message processData(Message message) {
def headers = message.getHeaders()
def properties = message.getProperties()

def messageId = headers.get("MessageId")
def tenantMoniURL = properties.get("TenantMoniURL")

def monitoringURL = "${tenantMoniURL}/shell/monitoring/Messages/%7B%22identifier%22%3A%22${messageId}%22%7D"
message.setProperty("MonitoringURL", monitoringURL)

return message
}

Step 3: Configure the Mail Adapter for HTML Alerts

Set the Mail Adapter body type to HTML and use this template:

Note:
Always ensure the Mail Adapter is set to HTML format, or the hyperlink will not render correctly.

Step 4: Test and Validate

  1. Trigger the iFlow (manually or via a test sender).
  2. Check your email for the alert.
  3. Click the hyperlink to verify it opens the correct message in SAP Integration Suite monitoring.

Main iFlow Alert Content modifier under Exception Subprocess:- 

Output Screen :

🔄Reusability

You can place this alert logic in a ProcessDirect-based reusable iFlow and call it from any other iFlow using an exception subprocess. This ensures centralized alerting and easier maintenance.

✅Benefits

  • Real-time visibility into failed messages.
  • Direct access to message monitoring.
  • Reduces manual effort in tracking errors.
  • Improves operational efficiency and SLA compliance.

📌Conclusion

Implementing a global alert mechanism in SAP Integration Suite is a best practice for proactive monitoring and rapid issue resolution. By leveraging Groovy scripting and HTML-formatted emails, you can deliver rich, actionable alerts directly to your support team.
